subject: RE: [junit] Do JUnit internals suck?!?
msgSnippet: There is a mixture of good design and bad/no design in JUnit. I spent many hours extending the framework for our own add-ons to JUnit. What I learned is that
messageBody:
There is a mixture of good design and bad/no design in JUnit.

I spent many hours extending the framework for our own add-ons to JUnit.
What I learned is that beyond the core patterns for the basic framework
(which are nice), design went out the window. Don't even look for model-view
separation. You won't find it there. Take a look at the classes in the
junit.framework.BaseTestRunner hierarchy for an example.

^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
Mike Silverstein
SilverMark, Inc.
The object testing company
http://www.javatesting.com

>
>
> > But I suspect that the people who discovered Design
> > Patterns/XP/Refactoring might have some idea on Object
> > Oriented design ;-)
>
> And I suspect that in that remark lies the crux of it. The common
> topics that appear when discussing the complexity of JUnit are Suites
> and Tests, where this is just a typical instantiation of the Composite
> pattern. The TestResult is a collecting parameter, and so on.
>
> I am one of those people who puts JUnit forward as an example to be
> followed, and am, so far, unswayed from that position. My views are
> based on the code for JUnit 3.7, but I can only imagine that it has
> gotten better, and not worse in the latest release.
>
> As is usually the case when using patterns in code, to the non-initiated
> any such code may look very complex indeed, and the relationships
> between the different classes unfathomable. The benefits for those who
> do recognise the patterns, however, is great.
>
